questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with a SLE presents for a routine follow up visit. She is compliant with her medication regimen containing hydroxychloroquine. An old friend of hers from high school recently passed away from a sudden pulmonary embolism, and the situation made her worried. She asks if she is at risk for a blood clot. What should you tell her?

options.label: A
options.text: Her risk of a thromboembolism is only elevated if she tests positive for antiphospholipid antibodies, which is only seen in 10% of lupus patients.

options.label: B
options.text: Her risk of a thromboembolism is only elevated if she tests positive for antiphospholipid antibodies, which is seen in about one-third of lupus patients.

options.label: C
options.text: Having SLE even without antiphospholipid antibodies is a significant risk factor for developing a blood clot

options.label: D
options.text: The longer one has had SLE, the higher the risk for a thromboembolism

questions.correct_answer: C. Having SLE even without antiphospholipid antibodies is a significant risk factor for developing a blood clot
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Having SLE even without antiphospholipid antibodies is a significant risk factor for developing a blood clot

questions.text: A previously healthy 41-year-old man suffers a minimally displaced distal radius fracture and is treated in a cast tor 4 weeks. He presents 14 weeks later with dorsal wrist pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Rupture of the extensor pollicis longus (EPL) tendon

options.label: B
options.text: Rupture of the extensor indicis proprius (EIP) tendon

questions.correct_answer: A. Rupture of the extensor pollicis longus (EPL) tendon
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Rupture of the extensor pollicis longus (EPL) tendon

questions.text: By which of the following mechanisms can hyperthyroidism and thyrotoxicosis increase the risk of osteoporosis in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Uncouples bone remodeling and shortens bone remodeling cycle

options.label: C
options.text: Release of tumor necrosis factor a and interleukins IL-1 and IL-6

questions.correct_answer: B. Uncouples bone remodeling and shortens bone remodeling cycle
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Uncouples bone remodeling and shortens bone remodeling cycle

questions.text: A patient with metastatic prostate cancer develops hypocalcemia during treatment with a bone antiresorptive agent. Which of the following agents is most likely to result in hypocalcemia?

A 7-year-old boy presents with recurrent skin infections and a history of easy bruising. On examination, the boy has patches of atopic dermatitis with overlying purpuric excoriations. Additionally, multiple molluscum contagiosum, verruca plana, and areas suggestive of eczema herpeticum are seen. Laboratory findings reveal thrombocytopenia. The patient's maternal uncle had a similar presentation and died in infancy. Based on the clinical and family history, which of the following congenital immunodeficiency disorders is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Wiscott-Aldrich syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • X-linked
  • • thrombocytopenia
  • • atopic dermatitis-like skin lesions
  • • secondary bacterial skin
  • • eczema herpeticum
  • • molluscum contagiosum
  • • verruca plana
  • • Wiscott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS)
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • B. Ataxia telangiectasia: This disorder presents with progressive cerebellar ataxia , ocular and cutaneous telangiectasias , recurrent sinopulmonary infections , and an increased risk of malignancy . There is no predominant skin infection or thrombocytopenia. C. Hyperimmunoglobulinemia E syndrome (Job syndrome): Patients have elevated IgE levels , recurrent skin and lung infections (often with Staphylococcus aureus), and skeletal and dental abnormalities . They do not present with thrombocytopenia or a history of X-linked inheritance . D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: Characterized by albinism , recurrent pyogenic infections , and peripheral neuropathy . Patients have giant granules in leukocytes. There's no association with an atopic dermatitis-like rash or thrombocytopenia.
  • • B. Ataxia telangiectasia: This disorder presents with progressive cerebellar ataxia , ocular and cutaneous telangiectasias , recurrent sinopulmonary infections , and an increased risk of malignancy . There is no predominant skin infection or thrombocytopenia.
  • • B. Ataxia telangiectasia:
  • • progressive cerebellar ataxia
  • • ocular and cutaneous telangiectasias
  • • sinopulmonary infections
  • • increased risk of malignancy
  • • no predominant skin infection or thrombocytopenia.
  • • C. Hyperimmunoglobulinemia E syndrome (Job syndrome): Patients have elevated IgE levels , recurrent skin and lung infections (often with Staphylococcus aureus), and skeletal and dental abnormalities . They do not present with thrombocytopenia or a history of X-linked inheritance .
  • • C. Hyperimmunoglobulinemia E syndrome (Job syndrome):
  • • elevated IgE levels
  • • recurrent skin and lung infections
  • • Staphylococcus
  • • skeletal
  • • dental abnormalities
  • • do not
  • • thrombocytopenia or a history of X-linked inheritance
  • • D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: Characterized by albinism , recurrent pyogenic infections , and peripheral neuropathy . Patients have giant granules in leukocytes. There's no association with an atopic dermatitis-like rash or thrombocytopenia.
  • • D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome:
  • • albinism
  • • pyogenic infections
  • • peripheral neuropathy
  • • giant granules
  • • Therefore, the most fitting diagnosis for the presented case is WAS , an X-linked recessive disorder . Bone marrow transplantation is a potential curative treatment for affected individuals.
  • • WAS
  • • X-linked recessive disorder
  • • Bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: A 63-year-old previously healthy woman with no significant medical history develops an abnormal EKG following the repair of a closed femur fracture sustained in a high-speed motor vehicle crash. The procedure was notable for mild tachycardia and hypotension but was otherwise uncomplicated. ECG shows 1-2 mm ST elevations in leads V2-V4 and deep T-wave inversions in V5, V6, and aVL. Serum troponin is 0.8. The patient undergoes an emergent coronary angiography, which reveals no evidence of acute thrombus formation. Which of the following additional findings is likely present?

options.label: D
options.text: Akinetic LV apex and mid-ventricular segments

questions.correct_answer: D. Akinetic LV apex and mid-ventricular segments
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Akinetic LV apex and mid-ventricular segments

questions.text: You are evaluating a 40-year-old woman in the neurology clinic who has been diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS) for the past five years. She recently started expressing feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and a loss of interest in activities she once enjoyed. She tearfully shares that she has never felt this way before. Upon reviewing her medication list, you identify several drugs used for managing her MS symptoms. Which of the following medications that she's taking could most likely be contributing to her newly developed depressive symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Interferon 1-beta

Explanation:

  • • Interferon 1-beta is a disease-modifying therapy used in the management of multiple sclerosis (MS). One of the recognized side effects of interferons, including Interferon 1-beta, is the development or exacerbation of depressive symptoms. When patients with MS on Interferon therapy present with new-onset depressive symptoms, it's crucial to consider the medication as a potential contributing factor. In such cases, monitoring the patient closely, collaborating with psychiatry, and potentially adjusting therapy may be warranted.

questions.text: An 84-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and spinal stenosis who was noted to have a sudden-onset tachycardia during preoperative evaluation. The patient received intravenous verapamil at which time she converted to normal sinus rhythm. Extended release verapamil was continued without further dysrhythmia recurrence.
In which of the following study designs, the Outcome of interest has already taken place when the study is started?

A 15y girl is brought by her mother to the OPD. She says that her daughter has not yet attained menarche. She has been doing well in school and is on the school basketball team. However, her mother has noticed her voice has deepened and there is coarse hair growth on the chin since a few months. When you examine her, you find there is no breast development. There is sparse pubic and axillary hair and on local examination you find there is an enlarged clitoris. A karyotype done, reveals 46XY and an ultrasound reveals an absent uterus. Which is the most likely possibility?
Which among the following laboratory investigation is best to reveal bleeding in Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation?

A 58-year-old female with exertional shortness of breath and forceful heart beating who sought medical attention and was discovered to have a loud systolic heart murmur with subsequent transthoracic echocardiography confirming a posterior leaflet mitral valve flail segment. This 12-lead electrocardiogram was obtained on her 2nd postoperative day following open-heart surgery in the form of mitral valve repair. What is the likely diagnosis based on the ECG shown below?
Which of the following mutations is associated with Crohn’s disease related primary small bowel adenocarcinoma?

Although the small bowel accounts for 75% of the length and over 90% of the surface area of the gastrointestinal tract, small bowel neoplasms only account for approximately 3% of gastrointestinal cancers. Which of the following is not a possible protective mechanism in the small bowel that accounts for the relatively low rate of adenocarcinoma in the small bowel compared to the colon?

options.label: A
options.text: Shorter transit times through the small bowel

options.label: B
options.text: Lower density of aerophilic gram-positive bacteria in the small bowel

options.label: C
options.text: Lower concentration of gram-negative bacteria in the small bowel

options.label: D
options.text: Higher concentration of microsomal enzymes in small bowel epithelia

questions.correct_answer: C. Lower concentration of gram-negative bacteria in the small bowel

questions.text: A patient is treated with cisplatin and bleomycin and develops renal failure. Which of the following is a characteristic of renal failure that may occur specifically when cisplatin is given with bleomycin?
A 23-year-old man with HL was treated successfully with the ABVD regimen. Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of this patient is cell cycle specific?
Which is the least important risk factor associated with developmental dysplasia of the hip?
A patient has the following laboratory findings: Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?

options.label: A
options.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis with mixed respiratory alkalosis

options.label: B
options.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis

options.label: C
options.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

options.label: D
options.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis with mixed respiratory acidosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent anemia and occasional gastrointestinal bleeding. On examination, numerous lentigines are observed on her mucous membranes as shown in the image below, digits, palms, and soles. Further evaluation reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps in her gastrointestinal tract. Her family history is notable for her mother having ovarian cancer and her aunt with breast cancer. Based on her presentation and family history, which of the following syndromes is she most likely to have, which is also associated with an increased incidence of gastric carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Explanation:

  • • The patient's presentation is indicative of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, which is caused by a mutation in the tumor suppressor gene STK11.
  • • Key features of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome include:
  • • Lentigines on the mucous membranes, digits, palms, and soles. Increased incidence of hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract, which can lead to symptoms like gastrointestinal bleeding. Although only 2-3% of these polyps may turn malignant, the most common sites of malignancy are the stomach and small intestine. Apart from gastric carcinoma, patients also have an increased risk of developing ovarian, breast, and pancreatic cancer.
  • • Lentigines on the mucous membranes, digits, palms, and soles.
  • • Increased incidence of hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract, which can lead to symptoms like gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • • Although only 2-3% of these polyps may turn malignant, the most common sites of malignancy are the stomach and small intestine.
  • • Apart from gastric carcinoma, patients also have an increased risk of developing ovarian, breast, and pancreatic cancer.
  • • Other options
  • • A) Gardner syndrome is primarily associated with malignant adenocarcinoma of the colon and rectum.
  • • C) Cowden syndrome: Mutations in the PTEN gene are responsible for the majority of cases. It is linked with follicular thyroid carcinoma, breast cancer, and endometrial cancer.
  • • D) Dyskeratosis congenita: Triad of nail dystrophy, lacy reticular pigmentation on the neck and upper chest, and oral leucoplakia. It is associated with mucosal squamous cell carcinoma, bone marrow failure, acute myeloid leukaemia, and Hodgkin disease.
  • • Given the patient's clinical features and family history, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is the most likely diagnosis, and it is also associated with an increased risk of gastric carcinoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a recent road traffic accident. He was involved in a high-speed collision and sustained blunt trauma to his abdomen and lower back. He complains of severe left-sided flank pain and haematuria. This was managed conservatively in view of AAST Grade 2 injury on CECT. During his in-patient stay, it was noticed that his BP is increasing while he was previously normotensive. His Baseline CECT is shown here. What is the likely explanation for his course?
In each scenario, choose the best plan for management:
Organize the listed bands within the sarcomere, starting from the periphery and moving towards the center. Z line M line A band H zone

A 49-year-old woman, gravida 5 para 5, comes to the office due to urine leakage. Over the last 2 months, the patient has had constant urinary leaking, requiring her to wear a pad day and night. She has no dysuria, urgency, or vulvar pruritis. The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus that is well controlled with oral medication. Two years ago, she received brachytherapy and external-beam pelvic radiation for cervical cancer. BMI is 43 kg/m. Pelvic examination shows no urethral leakage with Valsalva. There are post radiation changes and a pool of clear fluid in the vagina. Postvoid residual volume is 20 mL. Urinalysis results from catheterization are as follows: Specific gravity-1.004 Blood-trace Glucose-negative Leukocyte esterase negative Nitrites-negative Bacteria-few White blood cells- 1-2/hpf Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Aberrant connection between the bladder and vagina

options.label: B
options.text: Diminished contractility of the bladder detrusor

options.label: D
options.text: External compression of the urethral outlet

questions.correct_answer: A. Aberrant connection between the bladder and vagina

questions.text: Match the following X-rays with the correct cause of respiratory distress:

A 8-month-old child after vaccination presents to the emergency with incessant crying and legs drawn up. X-ray abdomen showed signs of free air. USG is done next which shows the following. What will you do next?
questions.correct_answer: A. Plan for urgent surgical exploration

questions.text: During surgery on a 56-year-old man for a squamous cell carcinoma of the neck, the surgeon notices profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery. Which of the following arteries must be ligated immediately to stop bleeding?
Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction. General somatic General visceral Special somatic Special visceral

44-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of a "mole." He has a slowly enlarging macule that was first noticed by his partner 6 weeks ago. The lesion has no associated pain or itching, but it has changed in colour from pink to violet. On review of systems, he denies fever, night sweats, or urinary symptoms. The patient reports an unintentional weight loss of approximately 8 kg over the past year. He was treated for syphilis 2 years ago with long-acting penicillin. He had multiple male sexual partners in the last 20 years and works as a freelance website developer. He does not use tobacco or illicit drugs but drinks alcohol heavily on weekends. Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 14/min. The skin lesion is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's skin lesion?
Identify the mismatch vascular anatomy in flap reconstructions in plastic surgery:

options.label: A
options.text: Pectoralis Major Myo-cutaneous flap - Acromio-thoracic artery

options.label: B
options.text: Antero-lateral Thigh flap - Medial circumflex femoral

options.label: D
options.text: Rectus abdominal - Deep inferior epigastric artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Antero-lateral Thigh flap - Medial circumflex femoral

questions.text: Which of the following findings suggest a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis in a patient with psoriasis, dactylitis, and tenderness in the sacroiliac joints?

options.label: D
options.text: Involvement of only the proximal interphalangeal joints of a digit

questions.correct_answer: B. Mouse ear sign on X-ray
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Mouse ear sign on X-ray

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with history of long standing goitre visits the OPD. Surgeon performs this manoeuver- which makes the patient breathless. This finding implies?
A patient is diagnosed with moderate psoriatic arthritis resistant to NSAIDs. Which of the following is recommended as first line therapy to prevent joint destruction?

A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with excessive bleeding following a tooth extraction. She has a family history of bleeding disorders. Laboratory tests show a normal platelet count and coagulation factor levels. Thromboelastography (TEG) is performed and reveals a normal R-time but a significantly decreased α-angle as well as reduced maximum amplitude (MA). What is the most likely explanation for these TEG findings?

A 35-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with joint pain and swelling. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of anti-citrullinated protein antibodies (ACPA) and rheumatoid factor (RF). Imaging studies show erosions and deformities in the joints. Further investigation reveals activation of caspase-4 and release of IL-1β and IL-18 in the synovial fluid. Which of the following forms of regulated cell death is likely contributing to the joint inflammation and damage in this patient?

A 70 Kg person was started on a drug with Vd =10 L and exhibits first-order elimination kinetics. The rate of drug clearance is calculated to be 6.93 L/hr. It is determined that repeating the second dose when 75% of the drug is eliminated will minimize toxicity while maintaining trough levels above the minimum inhibitory concentration. Based on these research findings, which of the following is the most appropriate dosing interval for this drug?

A 72-year-old woman with severe COPD who requires home oxygen is unable to ambulate inside her home without experiencing severe left hip pain. She was hospitalized 1 year ago for a viral pneumonia and was ventilator-dependent at that time for 6 weeks. On examination, her blood pressure is 165/80 mm Hg. She has weakly palpable bilateral femoral pulses. An angiogram demonstrates severe aorto-iliac disease involving bilateral iliac vessels. Which of the following is the most appropriate vascular procedure for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Common femoral and profunda femoral endarterectomies

questions.text: A 15-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by her concerned parents who report that she is not using her left arm. She had been in good health until recently when she developed a non-productive cough and a persistently runny nose. On physical examination, the infant is found to have a runny nose with purulent discharge, moist rales in the chest, a generalized rash, and hepatosplenomegaly. Additionally, a mucocutaneous rash is noted on the palms and soles. There's also evidence of painful movement and swelling of the left upper arm, suggestive of osteochondritis. Which of the following is most consistent with this infant's presentation in the context of early congenital syphilis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Pseudoparalysis of Parrot

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This infant's presentation is characteristic of Early Congenital Syphilis . Among the options provided:
  • • Early Congenital Syphilis
  • • A) Pseudoparalysis of Parrot is seen in early congenital syphilis in children less than two years old. This pseudoparalysis results from painful osteochondritis , which leads the infant to avoid moving the affected limb . The presence of symptoms such as a runny nose with purulent discharge ( rhinitis/snuffles ), generalized rash, hepatosplenomegaly , and the described pseudoparalysis are consistent with early congenital syphilis.
  • • Pseudoparalysis of Parrot
  • • painful osteochondritis
  • • avoid moving the affected limb
  • • runny nose
  • • rhinitis/snuffles
  • • hepatosplenomegaly
  • • early congenital syphilis.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • B) Higoumenakis sign is characteristic of late congenital syphilis and presents as a unilateral hyperostosis of the inner third of the clavicle.
  • • Higoumenakis sign
  • • C) Generalized paresis of Insane is a neurologic manifestation seen in tertiary syphilis, not early congenital syphilis.
  • • Generalized paresis of Insane
  • • D) Saber shins are a deformity of the anterior tibia seen in late congenital syphilis, as shown in the image below.
  • • Saber shins
  • • Hence, based on the infant's clinical presentation and age, Pseudoparalysis of Parrot due to osteochondritis is the most consistent finding with early congenital syphilis.

questions.text: I n a dramatic and action-packed South Indian film, superstar Rajnikanth finds himself in a critical situation where a sudden calamity has left several people unconscious and struggling to breathe. With his quick thinking and vast knowledge, Rajnikanth immediately grabs the device given below, from a nearby medical kit. He swiftly moves from patient to patient, using the manual resuscitator to deliver oxygen and successfully reviving each individual. All true about apparatus in picture except?

options.label: C
options.text: It is also called bag valve mask

options.label: D
options.text: It is used in only spontaneously breathing patients

questions.correct_answer: D. It is used in only spontaneously breathing patients
questions.explanation: Ans. D. It is used in only spontaneously breathing patients

questions.text: A 26-year-old male is evaluated for lethargy, somnolence, and jaundice. He does not take any medication and denies any drug or alcohol use. He is afebrile with normal vital signs. Exam is significant for a tremor and ataxia. He has no hepatomegaly, ascites, or cutaneous signs of chronic liver disease. Eye exam reveals no abnormality. Laboratory studies are significant for ALT 700 U/L, AST 850 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 119 U/L, total bilirubin 15 mg/dL, direct bilirubin 5.9 mg/dL, and INR 6.0. Hemoglobin is 10 g/dL with WBC 10,000/mm^3 and platelets 100,000. Acetaminophen screen is negative. Ceruloplasmin is 16, and 24-hour urine copper is 90 mcg. ANA is 1:20. Serologies for viral hepatitis are negative. Ultrasound of the liver is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best choice for treatment?
Patient with history of PR bleed is found to have this lesion on laparotomy. What does this signify?

In a gripping Bollywood medical drama, legendary actor Amitabh Bachchan portrays a renowned surgeon, Dr. Arjun Mehra. The scene unfolds in a high-tech operating room where Amitabh’s character is ready to perform a complex surgery. The atmosphere is tense, with the surgical team bustling around, preparing for the procedure. The patient is induced with Thiopentone IV through one of the antecubital veins. The atmosphere takes a sudden turn when the patient complains of severe pain engulfing his whole hand. The music intensifies, spotlighting Amitabh Bachchan’s concerned expression. What is the next line of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Give IV propofol through same needle

questions.correct_answer: C. IV lignocaine through same needle
questions.explanation: Ans. C. IV lignocaine through same needle

questions.text: A 41-year-old smoker presents to you with shortness of breath and you decide to do a pulmonary function test. Interpret his reports?
Identify the device:

Chetan, a patient in the emergency department, presents with severe drug-induced hypotension, registering a blood pressure of 75/50 mmHg. Over the years, you have managed acute hypotension from various causes using an intravenous injection of x mg of methoxamine. Given Chetan's medical history of taking his current medication for several months, and considering he shows no signs of volume depletion or hemorrhage, you administer the standard dose of methoxamine. Surprisingly, Chetan's response is unexpected and intense, causing his blood pressure to soar to 180/110 mmHg. Given this stark elevation in blood pressure post-administration, which of the following medications did Chetan most likely overdose on?

During your rural posting after the internship, you encounter a patient of acute cardiac failure. Your preferred drug for this condition is dobutamine. However, it is not available there. Which of the following other drugs, or combination of drugs, would be a suitable alternative, giving the pharmacologic equivalent of what you want the dobutamine to do?

Which of the following is true regarding the vaccine vial monitor (VVM)? It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VM. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VM is in an acceptable range. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.

A young female presented to you with primary amenorrhea. Examination reveals normal breast development and absent axillary and pubic hairs. Pelvic examination shows a normally developed vagina with clitoromegaly and micro-phallus. On ultrasound, masses are visible in the inguinal region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the likely diagnosis based on the images shown?

58-year-old, previously healthy man is evaluated due to a 2-month history of early satiety, postprandial epigastric pain and vomiting and unintended weight loss. Physical examination shows cachexia and palpable epigastric mass. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a large prepyloric mass causing gastric outlet obstruction; biopsy of the mass is consistent with poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Abdominal CT scan reveals thickening of the gastric wall with adjacent fat infiltration, enlarged lymph nodes, and multiple hepatic metastatic lesions. The disease is considered unresectable, and the patient undergoes laparoscopic gastrojejunostomy for palliation of gastric outlet obstruction. Postoperatively, he tolerates tube feeding but experiences worsening weakness. The patient also has frequent episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia. Laboratory results are as follows: Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's worsening condition?

An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus?
